comments.commentBody: Wouldn't any potentially pregnant woman have standing?

Indeed. This law is interfering with women's right to reproductive self-determination, which is a human right. No one but the woman herself should decide whether she wants a child or not. The state will not turn up to baby-sit, the state will not feed the baby and the state cannot mother it, therefore the state has no say in the matter. The state has no right to saddle the woman with these duties against her will.

The stories told here are staggering. And so many of them! Close to seven hundred since 1973!

The anti-choice brigade really has gone too far in United States. They should be held accountable. They should pay compensation to each and every one of these women for breach of their rights and to the relatives of the dead women.

It should be clear that the rights of a woman trump those of a fertilized egg or a foetus.

It is my closely held religious belief that what I do with my body is for me and me alone to decide. I hope someone with similar beliefs (and standing) will go to court to fight those who want to force their religious beliefs on the rest of society.

Another thought. There is a far larger principle at risk here than the legality of Obamacare. If we can "interpret" the language of this law in any way we wish, then effectively, there is no law. We have a government of men rather than a government of laws.
Lincoln was the only adult in the room.

Agreed har..Lincoln wasn't perfect. Some of the things he did would be cause for inquires today, however back then it was chump change compared to
what he did...saving America and ending slavery..

Despite the widespread myth that the presidential election of 1864 was the first to take place in time of are, in fact the election of 1812 was held despite the fact that we had declared war on Britain earlier that year.

This article is a useful reminder of the terrible pressures during the civil war that led to some corruption of the political process. But the essay lacks context because it omits any discussion of electoral practices during that era. The secret (Australian) ballot still lay in the future (1880s), so virtually nobody's vote was truly private. Also the evidence presented seems largely anecdotal and in some cases presented by enemies of the Republican party. This makes it almost impossible to determine how widespread (or effective) the pressure was. Nevertheless, it is sobering to be reminded that even Abraham Lincoln (or his allies, who surely did not act without his knowledge)
could not entirely resist the temptation to press his thumb on the scales of democratic decision-making.

FMLA is used for the caretaking of spouses and elders as well.  Most people, at some time or another would benefit  Unless you're so individualistic and isolated there is *nobody* you'd need to care for.
I see that even Supreme Court Justices confuse reticence with reluctance.

well thought out response--thank you.

unfortunately, I am not expecting a well thought out response from Scalia, Thomas, et al....

If the republicans on the court, especially Roberts and Alit, weren't sych fundamentally dishonest people, that might mean something. These guys work for the church, and their investors - capital interests), not for us.

The last time health care came up for review, Roberts shocked almost everybody by voting to uphold the law. Lots of analysts think he did that for political, rather than legal reasons--that is, to show that the Justices' votes are not dictated by their party affiliations. The first challenge to the ACA was constitutional, and Roberts made a big leap in voting as he did. This challenge is based on statutory interpretation, which allows way more leeway to the justices. In his first opinion, Roberts wrote: "Our permissive reading ...is explained in part by a general reticence to invalidate the acts of the Nation’s elected leaders. ... Members of this Court are vested with the authority to interpret the law; we possess neither the expertise nor the prerogative to make policy judgments. Those decisions are entrusted to our Nation’s elected leaders .. It is not our job to protect the people from the consequences of their political choices."

While, this is not the same reasoning that will be involved in the new case, Roberts' indicates a deference to Congress that is very encouraging. All is not lost.

They also didn't intend the President to think that he can pass law all by himself.

Funny thing, that Constitution.

"We as a nation have become uninformed buffoons..."

Yet you offer nothing about the case. It's a legal case, not a policy decision. If the law says something clearly (which it does in this case) then "intent" is irrelevant. The shame is on the drafting.

I was very disappointed that the dems and even Obama never mentioned his ACA accomplishment even once during the peak of the Ebola panic.

When all the Republican white bread and butter voters were losing their minds about ebola, they could have at least mentioned some thing like "Aren't you all glad that at least now we have ACA, and if someone -- your neighbor, your gardener, your cook, or your kid's baby sitter develops a fever they would immediately seek medical help and instead of trying to walk it off?"

Republicans never miss an opportunity to use fear about pandemics and other imagined threats -- usually for the detriment of public good. What's wrong in the Dems using it once in a while to advance something worthwhile?
The problem with your argument is that the law is very clear, such that no ageny interpretation is needed. You just dont like the answer.
Actually, no, the issue is what "state" means.
odd, then, that costs have dropped.

It seems that since the SCOTUS already ruled the penalty to be a costitutional upheld tax, then they will also determine that these 4 Virginians may have the choice of buying insurance (without the subsidy, if that's their choice) or paying the penalty, OR they could apply for the "hardship exemption" that they say they want because it is not directly infringed by the existence of subsidies. In fact, there are several exemptions that -- if they are actually poor -- they would probably qualify for, including #12, that they don't qualify for Medicaid because their "state did not expand eligibility for Medicaid under the ACA."

Judging by legislative history, what was clearly intended was that States refusing to establish their own exchanges NOT receive subsidies. See today's WSJ editorial on this point. It is largely because of this intent, and the black letter of the law, that a technical correction cannot fix the issue you refer to as a technicality. The IRS simply cannot be allowed to write regulations that conflict with a clear reading of the underlying statute, no matter the issue or who may be slighted. Lower courts honestly disagree on what that clear reading is. So, the issue must inevitably be decided by the SCOTUS, or else clarified by Congress. That Republicans now have majorities in both houses does not give the administrative branch license to short-sheet the constitutional process. This is an inconvenient truth.

These guys shouldn't even be taking this up, as it is obvious what was "intended." Virtually every bill has idiotic passages that require fixing, and of course this one is no exception. Everyone who knows anything knows this, and it is absurdly obvious that this is a mere technicality. But it is a technicality that could blow the whole thing up if 5 guys in robes decide that that is what they want to do.

Robert - Almost indistinguishable it may be, but Romneycare did not have the subsidy clause that is being challenged here, since it only applied to one state.  If Congress intended to apply the subsidy to the Federal exchanges as well as the state run ones, that is what the law should have said.  It did not, so it seems the intent of Congress is clear.

Yes, the democrats passed this law knowing it excluded states that did not set up their own exchanges. In fact they crowed about it in public and private. Precisely how bad elections led to bad law writing. Period.
What "election"--we have play elections with known results months before the events.  US elections are not honest in any respect.

Actually, the Supreme Court isn't really supposed to be as politically coordinated. But just like stripping voting rights to achieve their desired results, I'm sure they'll do what's necessary here as well to assure GOP "success," such as it is.
this is precisely how elections have consequences.

An acquaintance of mine got divorced because that was the only way she'd be considered poor enough to get health care for her son.  Ten years later, after her son was grown and on his own, she and her ex remarried. The way health care is financed in this country is insane.  (That's the kindest word I can think of to describe it.)

As a single payer supporter (for 20 years) I have to say there is not a snowball's chance in Hades that if the country could not tolerate the right wing, Heritage Foundation's "Obamacare" that they would tolerate single payer. Flush with the success of having defeated Obamacare they would be energized and triumphant about stripping down whatever meager social safety net there remains and drowning it in the bathtub. In politics success breeds success, and they have the momentum and the wind at their back.

Taking away health insurance from 20 million people... Makes for a lot of angry voters. I wouldn't count on a republican majority having anymore longevity than it did last time.

After a year or two of focussing on controlling women's wombs, redistributing income to the rich by taxing the working poor more... People will remember who they're dealing with.

Curious to know where this 20 million figure (prior to the election, I was hearing "40 million") comes from - to my knowledge the optimistic estimate of people signing up for Obamacare is about 8 million; some people think it's closer to 2-3 million because you should only count people signing up for the first time, not those who were forced to sign up because they lost the policies they had. You can't "take away" insurance from people who never signed up for it in the first place, whether or not it's available to them.

A lot of us in the single payer camp thought that the ACA, without a "public option," would perpetuate the insurance industry's stranglehold on American health spending, and that it would eventually fail and then we'd have the opportunity to legislate Medicare for all.

If the Supreme Court tears the heart out of the law (giving states the option to accept Medicaid expansion dollars or not was bad enough) and those 20+ million people lose their health insurance and the whole thing falls apart like Prohibition, perhaps we'll move to the inevitable end point--single payer--quicker and less painfully.
fatherjoyful - if I don't care to purchase a car, I am not fined for declining unless I drive a car on the streets.  There is not a blanket instance that I buy auto insurance.

If it's so clear, then why did Congress provide for a federal exchange to begin with? The law as a whole can't function without subsidies to the federal exchange, and there is a presumption of consistency given to legislation. The great thing is that the Conservative justices have so gutted the principle of legislative history that your videos of the "author of the law" have even less bearing then they otherwise would. All the matters is the text as written as seen through the classic cannons of statutory interpretation. If there is inconsistency, then  the text is ambiguous, and if it is ambiguous the IRS gets deference under Chevron.
With mega bucks of those who have a great. Deal to lose if we go to single payer.

Not sure what insurance companies do that adds value to our medical system ?

They redistribute income. I guess that's OK unless Obama does it.
Insurance companie provide CEOs who can be paid megamillions per year to taint US politics with dark money.

This case is really about insurance companies having the right to skim off the top at taxpayer expense.  Not sure what insurance companies do that adds value to our medical system, but this case will surely have an effect on their bottom line, depending, of course.

Yep, I keep thinking about the emigration option too... Maybe a different state?

Make sure to compare plans before signing up again - apparently prices are jumping around again this year with more competitors in the market.

Parents have affirmative responsibilities to care for their children; spouses have affirmative responsibilities to each other.

Other than that, even caring for an elder is a lifestyle choice. It's not required by law, and employers have no compunction against asking employees if another extended family member can take on that tasks.

The reason that the pipeline doesn't go to British Columbia is that building such pipeline over the Rocky Mountains would be impossible. The only real option is to route it down the Mississippi River Valley.

The last employment numbers that I recall reading: up to 3K workers for up to two years to build the thing, a pittance nationally. Then 30-50 people to operate it! This has nothing to do with jobs.

It is all about moving this dirt to a Houston freeport so that the oil companies don't have to pay any duties for import of the dirt or export of the refined products to Europe and Asia. None of that stuff will expand US petroleum availability.

Why go to Houston? Because British Columbia will not abide such a pipeline to their west coast. There is an idea now to move the junk to Canada's east coast, we'll see how that fares. In either case it can be Canada's debacle and boondoggle, not ours.

The pipeline will probably be approved and signed into law because the Koch bros bought Congress. Obama will fold because he wants to "Just get along". Then what? Deregulate and stop funding critical programs. Welcome to the govt of the corporations which are people. Both parties have money on their hands.

Oh and let us not forget that Obama will be impeached. A trial will be held and Toberts will oust his from office. And then all he'll will break loose.

Hope I am wrong but I just might be right.
Yes indeed bargain chip and folding.

Why did the Koch brothers buy the Senate? Number one on the Koch wish list is the Keystone KL pipeline. The president's tasks for the next 2 years is to protect Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, the ACA, prevent a notional voter suppression law and defeat the Keystone XL pipeline to prevent environmental disaster. My fear it will become a bargaining chip and the president will fold.

The GOP intends to turn the calendar back to 1955 the job of Democrats is one to find their backbones and dig in for a 2 year of trench warfare, until the reinforcements arrive in Jan of 2017. Democrats can hold the fort and succeed in 2016 if they remember why they are Democrats the party that believes that the purpose of government is to serve all of the people not just white rich ones.

The big lie about this pipeline is that it will not add to our energy independence as claimed and the dirty oil, which is super polluting , will go on the world market to be bought by China and India and will speed global warming.
